natural problem: Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. 0 < p \<and> p < 1 \<longrightarrow> probability p = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18) = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>z\<in>{1..6}. indicator {18} (x + y + z))"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18) = 1 / 216"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. 0 < p \<and> p < 1 \<longrightarrow> probability p = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18) = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>z\<in>{1..6}. indicator {18} (x + y + z))"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18) = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the probability that the sum of three numbers, each chosen from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, is equal to 18. The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>(a,b,c) \<in> {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b + c = 18}. 1) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 1 / 216"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>(a,b,c) \<in> {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b + c = 18}. 1) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the probability that the sum of three dice rolls is exactly 18? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "C = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "D = {a + b + c | a b c. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> c \<in> C}"
and h4 : "card A = 6"
and h5 : "card B = 6"
and h6 : "card C = 6"
shows  "card {x \<in> D. x = 18} = 1" "card D = 216"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "C = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "D = {a + b + c | a b c. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> c \<in> C}"
and h4 : "card A = 6"
and h5 : "card B = 6"
and h6 : "card C = 6"
shows  "card {x \<in> D. x = 18} = 1" "card D = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given three sets A, B, and C, each containing the numbers 1 to 6, find the number of ways to choose one element from each set such that their sum is equal to 18, and also find the total number of possible combinations when choosing one element from each set. The final answers are 1 and 216, respectively.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. probability x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "three_dice_sum_18 = (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18)"
and h2 : "sum_three_dice = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>z\<in>{1..6}. probability x * probability y * probability z * indicator {True} (h1 x y z))"
shows  "sum_three_dice = 1 / 216"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. probability x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "three_dice_sum_18 = (\<lambda>x y z. x + y + z = 18)"
and h2 : "sum_three_dice = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>z\<in>{1..6}. probability x * probability y * probability z * indicator {True} (h1 x y z))"
shows  "sum_three_dice = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability of getting a sum of 18 when rolling three fair six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 18 = (\<Sum>i\<in>{(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b + c = 18}. real (1::nat))"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}}. real (1::nat)) = 216"
shows  "P 18 = 1 / 216"
a_4.formal solution:

and h1 : "(\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}}. real (1::nat)) = 216"
shows  "P 18 = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the probability of obtaining a sum of 18 by rolling three six-sided dice (numbered 1 through 6). The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice_A dice_B dice_C :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice_A n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "1 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n \<le> 6"
and h3 : "dice_B n = 1 / 6"
and h4 : "1 \<le> n"
and h5 : "n \<le> 6"
and h6 : "dice_C n = 1 / 6"
and h7 : "1 \<le> n"
and h8 : "n \<le> 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (i, j, k). dice_A i * dice_B j * dice_C k) { (i, j, k) | i j k. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<and> i + j + k = 18 } = 1 / 216"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice_A dice_B dice_C :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice_A n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "1 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n \<le> 6"
and h3 : "dice_B n = 1 / 6"
and h4 : "1 \<le> n"
and h5 : "n \<le> 6"
and h6 : "dice_C n = 1 / 6"
and h7 : "1 \<le> n"
and h8 : "n \<le> 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (i, j, k). dice_A i * dice_B j * dice_C k) { (i, j, k) | i j k. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<and> i + j + k = 18 } = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Three fair six-sided dice, A, B, and C, are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on the three dice is 18? The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "three_dice_sum_18 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> k \<in> {1..6}. (if i + j + k = 18 then probability i * probability j * probability k else 0))"
shows  "three_dice_sum_18 = 1 / 216"

 *)

fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"

and h1 : "three_dice_sum_18 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> k \<in> {1..6}. (if i + j + k = 18 then probability i * probability j * probability k else 0))"
shows  "three_dice_sum_18 = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the probability of getting a sum of 18 when rolling three standard 6-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "prob_space P (\<lambda>_. 1/6) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "independent_events P (\<lambda>i. {i}) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "joint_distribution P (\<lambda>(a, b, c). a + b + c) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
shows  "P {18} = 1 / 216"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three fair, standard six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces is 18? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{216}
 ### Proof
 We quickly note that the only way for three dice to sum to 18 is for the face of each to be a 6.
 So, if each die is a 6, then the probability of this occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3} = \boxed{\frac{1}{216}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "prob_space P (\<lambda>_. 1/6) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "independent_events P (\<lambda>i. {i}) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "joint_distribution P (\<lambda>(a, b, c). a + b + c) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
shows  "P {18} = 1 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a fair six-sided die. If you roll the die three times and sum the results, what is the probability of getting a sum of 18? The final answer is $\frac{1}{216}$.
